story:
About Trendsetters 

 

I grew up in Louis H Pink Houses projects in the 90s. Home of dilapidated buildings, street fights, elevators carpeted with urine, dreams deferred, and people who look like me beaten down by their environment, 28 years later, and not much has changed. I see those same people hanging around project hallways, the subjects of RIP posters, in jail, or simply surviving their circumstances. This is the ghetto, and you dare not fight what is already predetermined: you will be here for the rest of your life, for the ghetto is not designed to foster growth.

 

Everyone loves the ghetto aesthetic, but no one cares about the ghetto community.

 

 

We’ve seen it time and time again, major fashion brands mimicking or flat out stealing trends derived from these poor communities and marketing it off and “new and hip” ideas. We’ve seen retailers upsell basic items like bamboo earrings for triple their value because when placed on a body that is not black, the value increases. These entities capitalize on the essence of these communities yet pour nothing into the development of them.

 

Coming from an environment like this where you understand that you will receive no help, you feel helpless. You feel as though where you are is where you will remain. There is no light at the end of the tunnel because your tunnel is the ghetto. I am a product of this community and an advocate for its experience.

 

 

Trendsetters is a photo series encapsulating the quintessence of the African American ghetto experience through portraiture. The series will be shot over the course of 6 months in New York, Los Angeles, and Atlanta. The photos will be curated into a monograph to be showcased in each featured city.

 

This project is an expression of appreciation and my declaration of care. Through my art, I hope to humanize and highlight an otherwise forgotten community while changing the narrative of what it means to be "ghetto." 

 

 

 

About the Artist

 

Yolanda Hoskey’s photography is an unapologetic ode to melanin. In this storytelling climate calling for change, she fights the system by creating flawless images of black art that she adorns as ‘a little creativity mixed with a little ghetto’.  

 

 

An East New York native, she uses her inbred New York swag to shake the room, challenging traditional social norms and putting use to the phrase “young, gifted, and black.”      

 

 

 

A graduate of the City College of New York, Yolanda holds a BA in Theater.  She now spends her post-graduate years producing content, creative directing, and of course, creating beautiful images, proof that artistic development is anything but linear. 

 

www.yolandahoskey.art 

www.instagram.com/ghettoyolie/

 

Ways To Support 

  • Donate to this campaign directly 
  • Share across your social/personal networks 
  • Share across IndieGoGo

story:
She Shoots Film are super excited to announce

Issue 3

Metamorphosis

She Shoots Film Magazine, Issue 3, Metamorphosis / Photo Gallery / Elizabeth Casasola

She Shoots Film is an independent publication that is dedicated to exploring life through the female gaze. The publication encourages, supports and draws attention to emerging and seasoned film photographers that make with a woman's eye.

We've been creating and producing since our inception on the digital front in 2014 and successfully crowdfunded our first print issue in early 2017. Since then we've published two issues of She Shoots Film - Self Portrait and MOTHER. Focusing on one theme per issue, we offer viewers and readers a living breathing record of women's experiences in the form of film photography, interviews and narratives by women. 

This campaign is a call out to support our third instalment and offering to the community - METAMORPHOSIS.

Our third issue examines the concept of METAMORPHOSIS from multiple angles with a mix of photography, interviews, personal essays, and reflections from the community.

 

This issue features interviews with...

Hazel Dooney

Cig Harvey

Nancy Rexroth

Aline Smithson

 

And photographic contributions from...

Laura Aubrée, Deborah Candeub, Sabrina Caramanico, Elizabeth Casasola, Lauren Hare, Mia Krys, Emma Perry, Paola Katherine Rodriguez, Emma Starr and Lisa Toboz.

 

And writing by...

Ruby Berry and Lilly Schwartz.

She Shoots Film Magazine, Issue 3, Metamorphosis / Interview & Photo Gallery / 

Aline Smithson / Founder and Editor-in-Chief of Lenscratch

 

Being a part of the world

We are grateful to have been sponsored by Blue Moon Camera and Machine (Portland, Oregon, US), Carmencita Film Lab (Valencia, Spain), CatLABS of JP (Massachusetts, US), The Fox Darkroom (Kensignton, Victoria, Australia) and Michaels (Melbourne, Victoria, Australia). 

Although this is still a passion project that is funded by endless hours of activity in the wee hours, we are seriously committed to having a physical presence in the world. 

We can be found all over the world in niche booky arty stores that we love! Everywhere from Victoria - Australia, to Portland - US, to London - UK, to Zurich - Switzerland, to ZheJiang - China, to Berlin - Germany to Dublin - Ireland...and more!

We also participated in this year's Photobook New Zealand Festival and the Melbourne Art Book Fair.

And we have stayed true to our mission to encourage, support and draw attention to emerging and seasoned film photographers that make with a woman's eye.

Our previous issues that have been making their way into different places, spaces and hands include Self Portrait and MOTHER. These issues feature work from incredible artists and writers such as Christine Alic, Romy Alizée, Joy Celine Asto, Laura Aubree, Marit Beer, Ruby Berry, Giulia Bianchi, Tabea Borchardt, Monica Calderin, Sue Murfin Cardaro, Irene Zóttola Carretero, Aletheia Casey, Gwendolyn Courtney, Nicole Cudzilo, Carol S. Dass, Dana de Luca, Inga Dinga, Dee Elegia, Dorothy Glenn, Nikita Gross, Angelea H-R, Cheryl Hanna-Truscott, Ellie Ivanova, Amy Jasek, Kira Kikla, Hannah Kozak, Sarah Lazure, Patti Levey, Stacy Arezou Mehrfar, Katt Janson Merilo, Vedrana Mijic, Clara Abi Nader, Yaro Neils, Heather Oelklaus, Celeste Ortiz, Maria Ovsyankina, Hilde Pank, Georgia Ponirakou, Clare Rae, Marisa Redburn, Vicki Reed, Almudena Romero, Vera Saltzman, Silke Seybold, Hilary Sloane, Alla Sorokina, Ksenija Spanek, Dana Stirling, Jenny Jacklin Stratton, Lisa Toboz, Rose-Marie Westling, Linda Wilson, Anna Yeroshenko and Irene Zóttola.

We've also featured countless artists on our Insta feed.

 

What others are saying about us

We've been interviewed by Polaroid Originals, Stack Magazines and Vice Creators.

She Shoots Film…

"has been a film photography publication

dedicated to exploring life through the female gaze...

Each issue is centred around a unique theme,

each one offering a raw and emotive selection of images and stories...

serving up some serious beautiful work that keeps us wanting more."

~ Jane Fayle, Polaroid Originals Magazine

 

"is filled with conversations on the way women photographers interpret the world around them,

exhibiting a visual history that is too often underrepresented."

~ Grace Wang, Stack Magazines

 

"highlights the beautiful, hazy aspect of old school film photography

- as seen through the female gaze."

~ Cailey Rizzo, VICE Creators

 

"is such a beautifully made, deeply moving issue. I didn't expect all this emotion

would rise to the surface as I was reading it.

A huge bravo and thank you to all who had a hand in putting it together.

I'm blown away."

~ Anne Silver, PRYME Editions

 

How the funds will be used

*PRINT. 

Simple.

Yet.

SIGNIFICANT.

The funds raised will take this issue straight to the printing press in Berlin, Germany!

*As in our last crowd funding campaign, we believe in transparency and showed our community exactly where the funds were used by emailing all contributors a clear break down.

She Shoots Film Magazine, Issue 3, Metamorphosis / Photo Gallery / Elizabeth Casasola

Specifications

Perfect bound magazine

An incredible selection of full colour and B&W images from 16 female artists, four interviews, two essays and a community survey

112 pages

10.433" x 8.26" in size

The third issue will be limited to 1500 copies

The use of 100% FSC® recycled pulp as we are still environmentally conscious folk

Challenges

If Issue 3, Metamorphosis, is fully funded [fingers crossed] we don't anticipate too many challenges. At She Shoots Film, we've got the photography, editorial and design talent we need to produce a great third issue, as well as our pre-existing relationships with a strong print house and a great fulfilment house.

If we do run into any problems, we promise to keep our community updated on our progress.

Timeline

August, 2018

[Ready, Set, G-O, GO!]

Indiegogo Campaign Launched

September, 2018

[Please HELP fund our project]

Project funded

September, 2018

[Our designer continues to get her design ON - go Lucy!]

Design completed 

October, 2018

[Final files sent to Medialis in Berlin, Germany - home of beautiful print jobs]

Printing

November-December, 2018

[That incredible moment where the copies start going to their new homes]

Shipping

Who We Are

She Shoots Film is a global group of women that use She Shoots Film as a platform to encourage, support and draw attention to emerging and seasoned film photographers that make with a woman's eye. 

Share

We understand that it's not possible for everyone to donate, so we'd really appreciate you sharing this campaign with your friends, family and through your socials. We know that sharing contributes and makes a genuine difference.

Facebook / Instagram / Twitter

story:
Upon relocation to Casper, Wyoming from Scotland I was hit by intense culture differences mixed in with “ordinary” American culture that I somewhat expected from movies, TV and other media, however nothing was to hit me quite like the first time I encountered a cowboy. I honestly didn’t even think cowboys still existed and that it is still considered a means to earn a living.

 I am fascinated with the ancient traditions and philosophies that were perhaps once considered the only way to live, and I have learned, to some people today it still is. In my photographs, I hope to display the ethos of the cowboy lifestyle and traditional Western United States culture.


 Since moving to Wyoming, I have somewhat become connected to the cowboy way of life and the scope of my photographs explore areas of the lifestyle, regalia worn, tools utilized, horses and other animals along with the working day to day duties, mentality and philosophy of the cowboy culture. 


 I use a variety of techniques and materials in my photography including film, digital and alternative processes. I like to mix a little of modern technology with old processes which helps to convey the modern cowboy yet historical traditions. In the future, I hope to continue studying this culture and bring what I learn to my photographs.

I am looking to raise around $5000.00 to cover travel costs to ranches across the United states. I posted on American Cattlemens facebook page asking for volounteer ranches to let me come an take photos. I got an overwhelming response from Ranches across the country-more than I was expecting! I have invites to Colorado, Taxes, Oklahoma, Oregan, California and more, but I simply cannot afford the travel expenses. I'd need flights, and rental cars as I expect most of these ranches to be in rural locations. I will need food and motel stays. I already have the camera equipment that I'll need.

The final product will be an archival documentary style photo book covering the different ways of branding and at different locations across the country.

If I do not reach my entire goal, the funds will still go towards photographing the American Western ways and I have 2 definite bookings already for brandings In Saratoga Wyoming, so the funds will go towards travelling there and other Western Photo books I can create closer to home.

 

The Impact

I believe the way of the west is dying and I want to document it before I goes completely. It is also very interesting to show different cultures and traditions to the rest of the world.

I have won several awards including an international photo contest (Viewbug)
 for my western and portrait photography.

I graduated with my Fine Art degree in Photography in 2014 at the same time as getting married, having a baby and finishing on a 4.0GPA! I am a determined little sucker...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

story:
About The Show

At its heart, New York: The First Ten Years is about my journey to find and embrace my creative voice as a New Yorker. Through these images, you’ll see the city as I see it: inspirational, beautiful, challenging, contradictory, and sometimes—lonely. 

This exhibit also marks a return to my love of alternative and historic photographic processes by incorporating prints using platinum/palladium, albumen, salt, and other techniques that date back to the earliest days of the medium. 

Working this way will require a number of custom tools and processes that are not commercially available. But the additional work is worth it because it allows me to be far more intimately involved in every step of the process. 

It also means that I will have the flexibility to choose what process will be best for each image. Some of these images will have started their lives on a memory card and end up being printed in a process that dates back to the mid 19th century. Others may have taken using some of my oldest antique cameras and printed using modern techniques. 

The result is a collection of work that doesn’t fetishize process—but celebrates the beauty of the image and the city itself. 

About My Work

As a self-identified observational photographer, my photographs capture natural—but specific—moments in time and space with little to no interaction with the subject of my work. Rarely working in series, I choose instead to create a body of work unified by my desire to evoke an emotional response in the viewer.

My post-production philosophy is one where I try to bring out the best elements of an image, while still staying true to the nature of the subject as captured by each of my camera’s unique optics. To me, the image is made in the camera, and simply tuned in post.

What Has Already Been Funded

I am incredibly happy to say that New York: The First Ten Years is partially funded by a DCA Premier Grant from Staten Island Arts, with public funding from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs. Those funds are already covering a number of the expenses for the show including: 

  • Gallery operation costs
  • Event insurance
  • Framing supplies
  • Hanging supplies
  • Installation costs
  • Publicity materials (printed and online) 
  • Materials transportation and shipping

Here’s What Still Needs to be Funded

However generous the grant is, it will not cover all the costs associated with mounting this show. So, to help close the funding gap, I am asking for your support. Here’s just a few things that your support will help fund:

  • Purchasing chemicals and paper for prints
  • Printer to create higher res negatives for contact prints
  • Building a new UV light exposure box that will help with printing
  • A more efficient print washer to cut down on resources required to rinse my prints
  • A 16x20 contact printer that will allow me to create larger images for the show 
  • Darkroom and studio hours for photos that I won’t be able to print in my home lab
  • Cost of creating and shipping all the wonderful perks that are part of this campaign

More About Me

I am an accomplished producer, photographer, and lecturer who approaches my work with a nod to history and a drive for inclusive innovation.

During my time at the Producers Guild of America, I oversaw digital media production for the PGA East as well as at the annual Produced By: New York conference. I launched and hosted the Produced By Podcast where I had the opportunity to talk about producing with guests including J. Miles Dale (The Shape of Water), Amy Pascal (The Post), Hutch Parker (Logan), Mark Johnson (Downsizing), Nina Kostroff Noble (The Deuce), Gigi Pritzker (Genius), Joe Berlinger (Intent to Destroy), William Horberg (The Promise), Peter Saraf (Loving), and Sarah Green (Loving).

Like many contemporary photographers, I have had numerous conversations about the nostalgia of analog versus the proficiency of digital, and which one suits our work better. I have recently come to the conclusion that for me, it isn’t a matter of having to choose between the two. Instead, I am embarking on a journey that allows me the flexibility to choose the best process for each image.

In addition to working with the Yonkers Film Festival as the Festival Producer, I also lead a lecture series on topics related to the history, aesthetic, and business of the film industry at the festival’s year-round home the Digital Media Arts Center in Yonkers, New York.

I have a Bachelor’s in Film Studies from the University of Colorado Denver, and a Master’s in Media Studies from the New School and I currently live in Staten Island, New York with my husband Ben and our cat Gemma Grace.

You can see more of my work on my website kevynfairchild.com as well as my Instagram.

story:
The beautiful people you see smiling and living in these pictures call home a tarpaulin tented squatters camp in Bouddhanath, Kathmandu. Although Indian of origin, most are without any citizenship papers for either India or Nepal. The camp has been here for 20 years and houses about 50 families originally from Bihar, the Punjab, Delhi and Rajasthan. They came to Nepal to escape the hot desert, water and food shortages and looking for work and education amongst the cool mountain air. Unfortunately the reality was very different and the children that were born here were left with little choice but to stay. Hidden away, this community is almost unheard of and unknown in Kathmandu, falling between the cracks of the substantial amount of international aid that gets pumped into the city and for development projects across the country.

We want to help them and we need your help. ‘We’ are Cinders and Azim, a couple from the UK who have been living and working in Nepal for the past 6 months. We arrived in Kathmandu with around 40 digital and film cameras and a hazy plan to run a participatory photography project of some kind (both of us are trained to run these projects by PhotoVoice UK). Introduced one day to one of the families living in the camp - seven charming brothers to be precise - we have since been visiting regularly, taking photographs, drinking sweet Indian chai, joining daily afternoon cricket matches on neighbouring scrubland. Getting to know these beautiful people and hearing their stories. Our hazy idea had found its home!

What we will do - and what we need

We have created this page to gather immediate funds to bring some joy to these incredible children. Always smiling and playing with everything and anything - babies play with match boxes, toddlers tie bits of rope and chain to become snakes – they are amazingly creative.

We want to help this wonderful community in a simple way, by focusing on artistic expression and play. This is not a large scale development project, but rather a very personal idea borne of a strong connection to the people we've met and discussions with them about what they want and need. It's the everyday stuff, the fun and happiness that 'normal' kids have that all these families want for their children....and it is something that we can deliver in our time here. Not promising something we can't give or see through.

  • Participatory photography project

Twice weekly over the month of April we will run workshops with children in the camp - jointly facilitated by young adults living there. The children will be provided with and taught how to use a camera. Through the medium of photography we aim to give the children a chance to express themselves by taking photographs, and to work together on something creative and fun. We will produce and provide them with prints of their work, but the project will focus on the process as much as finished results.

The cost of this is not huge. We already have cameras kindly donated from the UK, we have the children to give them to, we just need funds to:

  1. Print the pictures on a regular basis - the kids need their prints back immediately. Such an important part of this is building trust with the children and a schedule of twice weekly meetings throughout April must be stuck to and prints given back every time.
  2. Purchase additional materials such as card, marker pens and glue for the workshops, and a book for each participant to mount their prints in.
  • Cricket kit and arts-based toys
  1. Full-blooded games of cricket - played with hard red leather balls and typical subcontinental intensity - take place every afternoon on a piece of flat scrubland adjacent to the camp. These games bring immense happiness to otherwise gloomy days. Players from the camp have managed to accumulate most of what they need, but are still missing several key bits of kit - much of it protective! These can all be purchased locally in Kathmandu, but are too expensive. We'd love to help them - and it won't take much for them to have everything they need.
  2. We'd also like to provide paper, paints and creative materials. I have seen first hand how the girls cherish one small pot of nail varnish or tube of henna. I know they would be the same with paints and art materials. We will incorporate some art into the workshops and teach them some techniques they can practise on their own.

So you can see we are not trying to collect thousands, or even really hundreds. Just enough to develop their pictures and buy them some cricket kit and art materials/toys.  Even £2 from you with a quick and easy click would mean SO much to them….after the printing costs obviously the more money you can give the more supplies we can buy them but we are aiming for a starting target of $500.

We will update the photographs regularly as well as documenting the workshops and the kids in their cricket kit and with their cameras! We are in the process of creating a platform for these images which you will be able to access from this link.

So that's it really...but please read on if you have time...

We absolutely have to work with these families and photography, already able to see what joy it will bring. Having a lot of disposable cameras as we do was always a worry for a participatory photography project…you would be amazed at the snazzy digital cameras even the poorest kids are playing with these days! But spending time with these families, knowing what they have to play with and seeing their reaction to handling prints we have given them we have NO DOUBT IN OUR MIND we must work with them and how valuable just this human contact is to the development of these incredible, but incredibly vulnerable, children.

We are on a short deadline and this definitely won’t be a textbook participatory photography project. This will be a series of visits about love and happiness, playing and creativity in a pretty challenging environment. We want to show them that they are important, valued and not forgotten. Having ownership of a camera, capturing their daily lives, their relationships, ‘their’ days is going to give them such a sense of importance, belonging, worth. But above and beyond all this it will make them happy.  They will smile, they will be being creative and they will have some very special photographic prints to keep as their own valuable possessions, when they have little others. The importance of this ownership of a seemingly valueless object in a humans feeling of self worth is well documented and immeasurable.

Thank you for reading and for your support.

story:
On 27th of May I will hang my photographs at the Strand Gallery in London for a week long exhibition that will mark the beginning of my career as a photographic artist.

That week will be my chance to speak to as many agents, galleries, critics, magazine editors and journalists as possible.

I have only four months to find the funds, print the photographs, get them framed and get the word out to as many people as possible.

And I will need your help to do all this.

My work and background

On my 18th birthday my father gave me a 24mm lens. That lens triggered a lifelong passion and to this day every photograph I take uses that lens.

For 22 years I have travelled the world, capturing precious moments and landscapes, all the while developing my own personal style and a significant body of work.

During that time the world of photography been transformed by the arrival of digital.

There are many advantages to digital photography, yet I remain unconvinced that it should ever replace the magic of the darkroom.

Despite the pressures to convert to digital my love and passion for analogue photography has continued to grow. The restrictions and apparent inconveniences of using film remain an integral part of my working style.

I still shoot in B&W, always using Kodak T-MAX 400.

I print my own photographs, never cropping them. They are gimmick free, relying purely on the strength of their disrespectful composition, strong subject matter and broody atmosphere.

So why exhibit now and what does the future hold?

With iconic brands like Kodak facing bankruptcy, I am afraid that film, along with all the excitement and wonderment I experienced as a teenager, is at risk of becoming obsolete. Photography students, for example, will often go through their entire course without entering a darkroom.

It is time to celebrate the power of film, and I intend to get my work out there and use it to evangelise about what I believe in.

During the exhibition I will invite students and kids to come and talk to me so I can share the skills, knowledge and passion I've developed over those 22 years. Seeing darkroom prints and speaking directly to the photographer will, I hope, inspire the students and increase the likelihood of them developing skills in analogue photography.

The plan is for this exhibition to be the first in a series of shows and projects across the UK and Europe - I have already been approached about the possibility of taking it to Milan.

Once the images are printed and framed it will provide me with a base from which I can evolve and adapt the exhibition for future themes, venue requirements and new work.

I am currently working on two major photographic projects: 'West of the Sun', a collection of landscapes and 'Festivities', a look at traditional celebrations and festivals, both secular and non secular from around the world. I will be able to use the frames, contacts and momentum from this exhibition to work towards completing these two projects.

On top of this I am running an online writing and poetry competition - using my images as inspiration - which I am hoping will culminate in another exhibition.

Now that I have started on this mission, I will not be stopped.

Your support

The costs of producing an exhibition, as you can imagine, are sizeable: Venue hire, framing, photographic and darkroom materials, PR, communications, posters, invitations, catering, storage, transport - they all add up. And while I can, and will, invest some of my own cash, I just don’t have access to all of the resources I need.

The entire budget for the exhibition is $15000 or £10000 so your contributions will make up half the budget and I will cover the remainder myself.

It is important that the target budget is reached in order to ensure the exhibition fulfils all of its potential and promise. If my goal here is not reached, however I will do everything I can to ensure a scaled down version goes ahead, so rest assured, your contributions will not be wasted.

So -

If you like the photographs you have see here, the highlights of a 22 year obsession, and believe they should be shown...

or if you, like me, are passionate about the art of photography...

or believe that the purity and depth of film should be celebrated...

or want to make sure future generations have the chance to learn the craft of analogue photography...then please contribute now.

I have put together a whole range of fantastic rewards and benefits including prize draws, discounted original prints, sponsored prints, portfolio reviews and tuition sessions. They really do make it worth getting involved, so please, have a look.

In Conclusion

This exhibition is not only an investment in my future as a photographic artist, but a celebration of the enduring power of film and photography - of a dying art as it attempts to resurrect itself.

I intend to play a part in this resurrection in whatever way I can and this exhibition is a perfect starting point and ideal platform.

I hope you decide to join me on this exciting journey

Thank you so much.

The Gallery:

Strand Gallery,
32 John Adams Street,
London WC2N 6BP,
www.Proud.co.uk

28th May to 3rd June 2012
Opening hours: 1100-1900

Private view 31st May 1800-2000

 

The team

As a measure of my seriousness I have put together an experienced team of producers, designers and assistants, who love my work and support my passions. They have agreed to work with me, to help make sure this inaugural event is a success and a springboard to an expanded programme.

Katz Kiely - Executive Producer

Katz is a highly experienced entrepreneur and producer. She has agreed to work closely with me, overseeing the exhibition and PR activity, providing me with invaluable advice and knowledge.

You can view her Linkedin page here.

Bakul Patki - Production Manager

Bakul is a creative consultant specialising in, producing and promoting arts projects. She is currently producing and curating the Sky Rainforest Rescue exhibition with Sebastião Salgado and Per Anders Petterson which has just moved from Somerset House in London and will open in the Gallery of Photography in Dublin in March.

You can view her Linkedin page here.

Jim Shannon - Designer

Jim is a creative professional, working as an illustrator, art director, copy writer and web designer - as well as a photographer.

He was the designer and programmer for my website and will be working with me on all the design and art work behind the exhibition, including invitations, posters and catalogue.

You can view his website here, his photography here and his Linkedin page here.

Brook Downton - Film Editor & Musician

Brook is a creative digital producer. He specialises in experiential and online digital campaigns, live event digital & multi-device, fully integrated products.

Brook was a huge help editing the material for the video - including trying to save the dodgy sound and picture quality - and provided the background music from his repertoire of beautiful compositions.

We will also be collaborating on a piece of music written specifically for the exhibition itself.

You can view his Linkedin page here or view his personal website here where you can also hear his music.

Combined Mind - Partners

Combined Mind is a creative media networking production company. They provide opportunities for career development, employment, training, investment and ultimately the commercial realisation of ideas.

They will be working with me on promotion and sponsorship.

You can view their website here.

Brook Downton - Film Editor & MusicianBrook is a creative digital producer. He specialises in experiential and online digital campaigns, live event digital & multi-device, fully integrated products.
Brook was a huge help editing the material for the video - including trying to save the dodgy sound and picture quality - and provided the background music from his repertoire of beautiful compositions.
We will also be collaborating on a piece of music written specifically for the exhibition itself.
You can view his Linkedin page here or view his personal website here where you can also hear his music.
Combined Mind - PartnersCombined Mind is a creative media networking production company. They provide opportunities for career development, employment, training, investment and ultimately the commercial realisation of ideas.
They will be working with me on promotion and sponsorship.
You can view their website here.

story:
Short Summary

During the academic year of 2016-2017, Kennesaw State University is observing the Year of Russia. The campus of the University arranges special events on a regular basis, featuring a different country each year. Each of these events is dedicated to a certain country.

Kennesaw State University offers more than 150 undergraduate, graduate and doctoral degrees to its more than 35,000 students. It is one of the 50 largest public institutions in the country and the third-largest university in the state. The KSU draw students from throughout the region and from 92 countries across the globe.

Each year Kennesaw State University is organizing lectures and seminars  with  economists, political scientists, and historians for performance.  The goal is to share KSU students the culture and history of foreign countries. 

Under the direction of Daniel J. Paracka, Ph.D. Director, Campus Internationalization Division of Global Affairs, Professor of Education, Interdisciplinary Studies Department of KSU the Year of Russia is part of an ongoing program featuring a different country each year.

For the Year of Russia Dr. Paracka  in partnership with premier Russian-language newspaper in Georgia, “The Russia House” is organizing a photography exposition  at KSU campus. According to his firm belief the visual arts are an integral part of a country’s culture.

Dr. Paracka has chosen 25 photographs of Oleg Koryagin. These photographs were taken in Moscow, Saint Petersburg, and other cities and towns of Russia, not so well-known and therefore they are of a particular interest.

This exhibition is meant to expose KSU students, even those not studying Russian culture and history, to gain a deeper understanding and appreciation of these centuries old culture. This includes Russia’s enduring contributions to the arts, which are timeless and without borders.

We have all heard the saying, “A picture is worth a thousand words”. Photography is a powerful tool for visual information. Students, or anyone else for that matter, can easily appreciate a photographic representation of a culture more easily and with more appreciation beyond that provided only by lectures or textbooks. When that photography of different places and times is created by a professional, the impact of understanding a culture by young students can be more effectively presented and appreciated.

Since the project is non-profit, its implementation depends entirely on the effectiveness of a fundraising campaign. We are very optimistic and excited about the future and confident in prospects of our project. According to our estimates, the amount required for the organization of this exposition is $6,800.  

Oleg Koryagin has been a professional photographer for more than 30 years. Following his graduation from the Moscow State University, Department of Journalism, he was invited to work for the largest information agency in the Soviet Union, published both at home and in foreign countries.

Without a doubt, professional photographers know how to shoot in different genres and conditions. However each photographer has his/her own favorite subject, genre, and style. Having traveled a lot throughout the homeland and around the world, Oleg has created his own style in travel photography.

Oleg’s photography is not a travel guide but a collection of the author’s prints, sometimes unexpected but always impressive. Even the most popular routes trodden by tourists far and wide appear from a new angle in his works. This is the art of photography at its best!

Not surprising over 100 his photographs were presented at a solo exhibit in France in 2012. Later, some of these pictures accompanied by the text were published in California, in the almanac of Russian authors living in the USA.

What We Need & What You Get

According to our calculation, the amount of an estimated $6,800 is enough for preparing and holding the exposition. This amount is distributed as follows:

Budget $6,864

Exposition: 25 printed large-scale and applied to plexi $150 each = $3,750

Hardware for Installation $25 each x 25 = $625                 

Additional texts printed for exhibition $350

Leaflet designed & printed for exhibition $750           

Crating and shipping costs for exhibition $315

Indiegogo fees $624

Cost for Perks $450

Having taken the decision to look for the help of sponsorship, we will be happy to express our respect and gratitude to those who seem it possible to become our donors. For this, we provide several options. Each person who makes a donation to our fund will be mentioned on the list of sponsors. This list will be arranged on a banner at the opening of the exposition. In addition, we will send to our honorable sponsors the samples of Oleg Koryagin’s works as postcards, photographs printed on paper or canvas with a note of gratitude from the photographer. We will attach a brochure about KSU exposition, information about author, and list of all sponsors.

What happens with the donations, if we don’t collect the necessary amount? If the amount of money collected is not enough for preparing and holding of the exposition in the form we plan, we will simply reduce the number of photographs presented at the exhibition. In other words, if we are not able to print 25 photographs of 24x36 size, we will print 20… 17… 15… or even 10. No matter what happens, the exposition has to be held, and we will do our best to make it happen. We are sure that with your help we will be able to achieve our goal.

The Impact

Photography was invented almost 200 years ago. Due to the development of digital technology, it has become a total obsession. Having become available to the public, photography is still the art form. Organizing the exposition of photographer Oleg Koryagin, we are sure it will be interesting to Kennesaw State University students. This belief is based on the high quality work of the author, his talent, and ability to show the familiar and habitual images in a new way. Surely, we are encouraged by a large number of positive comments regarding the exhibition held in France, as well as the positive evaluation of his work among colleagues. Moreover, we are sure that students in fact always meet “new” with huge interest: new knowledge, new experience, especially if this “new” is presented in an exciting and vivid manner. Unique photographs about Russia, its history, culture, and Russia today will be seen not only by thousands of KSU students but by significantly more people who are interested in photography as the art.

Other Ways You Can Help

It's understandable that making a monetary contribution isn't always easy. If you're not able to, no worries. Perhaps you can help in other ways! Please, spread the word. Repost and share this campaign on your social media site and it definitely will help us to make our project real! Simply help us make some noise about our campaign. Any support is appreciated!

If you know of any space that would be willing to host this exhibition in a future, please get in touch!

Thank you!

story:
A Short Summary

My name is Martha Rial and I am independent photographer based in Pittsburgh. I have dedicated my 35-year career to photographing stories I believe are critical to understanding the human condition. I work hard to go beyond the stereotype and find the joy in the humanity that bonds us all. 

Children working on handwriting at The Great Kings and Queens Children Centre.

_________________________________________________________________________

In November 2015, I spent 15 days photographing the work Bright Kids Uganda and The Great Kings and Queens Children Centre are doing to support children in Uganda.  The East African nation is widely considered to be among the poorest and most politically corrupt countries in the world. In this nation of almost 39 million people, an infamous civil war waged by Joseph Kony's Lord’s Resistance Army has resulted in tens of thousands of casualties, extreme torture and atrocities, and the dislocation of more than a million people. Nearly half the population is under the age of 15, and an estimated 2 million children have been orphaned.   

Murray Horne, curator of visual arts for the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust, has invited me to present my photographs from Uganda at Gallery Liberty 937 opening on September 23, 2016. 

The In Uganda, A School to Call Home  exhibit marks my first solo show since my 1998 Pulitzer Prize-winning essay Trek of Tears, which captured the tragedy of Rwandans and Burundians displaced by ethnic conflict. That collection of photographs traveled around the country and abroad for more than decade. 

Victoria Nalongo Namusisi at her childhood home near Entebbe. 
_________________________________________________________________________

I was introduced to Bright Kids Uganda co-founder Victoria Nalongo Namusisi at the University of Pittsburgh by Dr. Lou Picard in 2012. Namusisi co-founded the school and orphanage 15 years ago after several successful careers as a sport journalist, Olympic track team coach, government official and the head of scouting in Uganda. 

While in Uganda, Namusisi introduced me to former street kid Medi Bugembe who ran away from home when he was five years old.  Namusisi rescued Medi from the streets when he was 11-years-old. 

Medi joined other children who were neglected, orphaned or victims of extreme poverty at her newly opened Bright Kids Uganda orphanage where he was enrolled in school and encouraged to find his own path. After studying to become a teacher, Medi opened his own orphanage and school, The Great Kings and Queens Children's Centre, on the outskirts of Kampala. Many of the children come from the same streets where he fought for survival. 

Both projects I photographed—The Great Kings and Queens Children’s Centre and Bright Kids Uganda— have a connection to the Pittsburgh community. Pittsburghers have supported these projects financially and through educational outreach of the University Pittsburgh’s Ford Institute for Human Security, a program of the university’s Graduate School of Public and International Affairs (GSPIA). This exhibition is the culmination of a three-year planning process  and the willingness of the subjects to share their life stories with the world. 


A Bright Kids Uganda outing on Lake Victoria.
_________________________________________________________________________


What We Need

Producing a solo show is an extremely expensive burden for an artist and I don't want to miss this opportunity to share Victoria and Medi's stories with Pittsburghers and beyond. My goal is to raise $2500.00 to cover the production (printing and mounting the photographs) for my exhibit and to provide modest honorariums for my subjects Victoria Nalongo Namusisi and Medi Bugembe who are traveling to Pittsburgh from Uganda to participate in a community forum. 
I hope contributors will take advantage of this unique opportunity to own one of my photographs. I have received some support from the Ford Institute for Human Security at University of Pittsburgh's Graduate School of Public and International Affairs and a small Artist Opportunity Grant from the Greater Pittsburgh Arts Council, but it is not enough to cover my expenses. 
Master printer Tom Underiner, of Pixel River, is donating his expertise by creating limited edition prints for contributors at the $100, $250 and $500 levels. Hahnemühle, creator of beautiful fine art papers, has generously donated paper to our project. 

What You Get

As you can see, our perks are listed with the titles in Luganda, the local dialect spoken where Victoria and Medi live. In showcasing the beauty of these two strong and empowered individuals and their work through photography, it is also an opportunity to experience a unique world culture. Through learning bits of a new language, we hope to provide that connection to you, our backers.
In addition, those of you who back the campaign at select tiers BEFORE SEPTEMBER 12TH will have your name or the name of your business featured as event sponsors at the exhibit opening. Find out more in the descriptions below!

[$10] Wewali (way-buh-lay)

Wewali is the simplest way in Lugandan to express gratitude. It means "Thank you" and there is no better word to express our appreciation for your support of this campaign than for you to receive a wewali post card from Martha herself.

[$25] Kwesima (K-wess-eem-uh)

Kwesima means happiness. We included this title because your support of the exhibition through our Indiegogo campaign makes us grateful and has a lasting effect on the true beneficiaries, Victoria and Medi. The exhibit is one way in which their stories can be told and therefore, we will be sending you a 5X7 print of an image from the exhibit selected by Martha, a memento of the lives you have brought happiness to. You will also receive a shout out on the "In Uganda: A School to Call Home exhibition" Facebook Page.

[$50] Okulimirirwa (Oh-coo-lee-meer-eer-wuh)

Okulimirirwa means selfless. At this level, backing our campaign by September 12th will make you a sponsor of the In Uganda, A School to Call Home exhibition at 937 Liberty Gallery. Your name or the name of your business will be displayed among other sponsors and you will receive a 5x7 print featuring an image from the exhibit, signed by Martha Rial. 

[$60] Okutabula (Oh-koo-tah-boo-luh)

This surprise perk is your opportunity to okutabula, or travel, in true Ugandan style with custom-made Ugandan sandals. They are made with leather, hand sewn and stamped, and can be put though the test for wear and tear with their tough soles. In backing at this level, you will receive a pair of leather hand crafted sandals from Ugandan artisans. This perk also supports an acid-attack survivor, who started the business to provide an income after her attack. We will also give you a shout out on our Facebook page!
Following the completion of the campaign, we will contact you via Indiegogo to choose the sandal  size  (based on a chart that will be included) and design you prefer, selected from those featured below. With two neural and two beaded options, these sandals make the perfect  gift to compliment any guy or gal's wardrobe.
Design (1)

Design (2)

Design (1)

Design (2)


[$100] Amanyi (Ah-mahn-yee)
At this level, you have the opportunity to acquire an archival print size 9x12-in signed by Martha Rial, one chosen BY YOU from a gallery of 5 photos. You will also receive a shout out on social media and receive a post card from Martha. The prints from this exhibit, display the "amanyi" or strength of their subjects: Victoria, Medi, and the children they empower. Additionally, backers at this level prior to September 12th (that's within the first week of our launch!!!) will be featured on a sponsor board at the exhibit.

[$250] Bulungi (buh-loon-gee)

Bulungi, Luganda for "good" or "beautiful" sums up the exciting opportunities unlocked through supporting this level. At the $250 perk you will receive a 16x20 limited edition print of an image from the exhibition that you can choose from a gallery of 10 images (expanded from 5 offered in a previous tier). Martha will sign the print and you will forever own a piece of a beautiful story printed in the finest quality.

[$350] Amoyo (Ah-moi-oh)

Martha has created a special perk for donors in the Pittsburgh metropolitan area; she will make a portrait of you for $350. One family member, friend or significant other may join you for the portrait. Time not to exceed one hour. You can choose two images from our portrait session for personal use.  Location can not be more than 25 miles from downtown Pittsburgh. Amoyo is Luganda for "self" in the way that it refers to the heart and mind. What better way is there to capture a beautiful heart and mind of a generous supporter than in a portrait?


[$500] Mukwano (muh-kwon-oh)

Mukwano in Luganda means "friendship" and in supporting this campaign through backing the $500 tier, we cannot count you as anything but a great friend. Backing at this level will get you and a guest an invitation to an intimate  evening with Medi, Victoria, Martha, and ASA Social Fund Board Members consisting of dinner hosted by an ASA Board Member at the end of September. In addition to an evening of conversation and cultural immersion, you will also receive a 20x24 limited additional archival print chosen from a gallery of 10 images and signed by Martha, a reminder of the new friends you helped.

The Impact

My goal is to inform and engage the Pittsburgh community and beyond in the recognition of global human security issues and the important work Pittsburghers are doing to support and empower Uganda’s youth and most vulnerable populations. 

Classrooms at the  Great Kings and Queens Children Centre. 
_________________________________________________________________________
 

Providing an authentic context for this exhibition is paramount to its success, so I am pleased Medi Bugembe and Victoria Nalongo Namusisi will be speaking at  Community Forum: Stories from Uganda on the evening of Thursday, September 29th in Pittsburgh. This event is designed to help the public engage with the work and understand its social context (Their travel expenses are covered by ASA Social Fund for Hidden Peoples.) 

Also speaking at the forum is Dr. Louis Picard, Director of International Development Programs and professor of Public and International Affairs and African Studies at the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs (GSPIA) at the University of Pittsburgh. Several GSPIA students will share their experiences as recent interns with these programs. 


Risks & Challenges

Although I have received national attention for my work, mainstream art galleries are not always interested in showing my work because I choose to focus on social justice issues. It has been extremely challenging to obtain the necessary resources to produce an exhibition of this scope.  

This project is more than an art exhibit, it is about providing an accurate and thoughtful portrait of the children Victoria and Medi are helping. It is important to me to share the lessons I learned from photographing Victoria and Medi and their programs. They taught me the real meaning of family and how you can make room in heart for others regardless of faith and circumstance. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with family, friends and extended social networks. Thank you! 

Please attend the public opening on Friday, September 23rd which is held in conjunction with the Cultural Trust Fall Gallery Crawl. 

We would also love to see you at our Community Forum: Stories from Uganda on September 29th at Gallery 937 in downtown Pittsburgh. Reception at 6 p.m. and Talk at 7 p.m. Free and open to the public. 

Please check out these organizations that support children in Uganda. 

ASA Social Fund for Hidden Peoples

http://www.asasocialfundforhiddenpeoples.org

Bright Kids Uganda - Africa

http://brightkidsuganda.net

Noah's Ark Hands on Training Center

http://noahsarkug.org 

Stay up to date on the exhibit and related events by giving us a "like" on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/InUgandaByMarthaRial/?...

You can choose two images from our portrait session for personal use.  Location can not be more than 25 miles from downtown Pittsburgh. Amoyo is Luganda for "self" in the way that it refers to the heart and mind. What better way is there to capture a beautiful heart and mind of a generous supporter than in a portrait?

[$500] Mukwano (muh-kwon-oh)
Mukwano in Luganda means "friendship" and in supporting this campaign through backing the $500 tier, we cannot count you as anything but a great friend. Backing at this level will get you and a guest an invitation to an intimate  evening with Medi, Victoria, Martha, and ASA Social Fund Board Members consisting of dinner hosted by an ASA Board Member at the end of September. In addition to an evening of conversation and cultural immersion, you will also receive a 20x24 limited additional archival print chosen from a gallery of 10 images and signed by Martha, a reminder of the new friends you helped.

The Impact
 My goal is to inform and engage the Pittsburgh community and beyond in the recognition of global human security issues and the important work Pittsburghers are doing to support and empower Uganda’s youth and most vulnerable populations. 

Classrooms at the  Great Kings and Queens Children Centre. _________________________________________________________________________ 
Providing an authentic context for this exhibition is paramount to its success, so I am pleased Medi Bugembe and Victoria Nalongo Namusisi will be speaking at  Community Forum: Stories from Uganda on the evening of Thursday, September 29th in Pittsburgh. This event is designed to help the public engage with the work and
understand its social context (Their travel expenses are covered by ASA Social Fund for Hidden Peoples.) 
Also speaking at the forum is Dr. Louis Picard, Director of International Development Programs and professor of Public and International Affairs and African Studies at the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs (GSPIA) at the University of Pittsburgh. Several GSPIA students
will share their experiences as recent interns with these programs. 

Risks & Challenges
 Although I have received national attention for my work, mainstream art galleries are not always interested
in showing my work because I choose to focus on social justice issues. It has been extremely challenging to obtain the
necessary resources to produce an exhibition of this scope.  
This project is more than an art exhibit, it is about providing an accurate and thoughtful portrait of the children Victoria and Medi are helping. It is important to me to share the lessons I learned from photographing Victoria and Medi and their programs. They taught me the real meaning of family and how you can make room in heart for others regardless of faith and circumstance. 

Other Ways You Can Help
 Please share this campaign with family, friends and extended social networks. Thank you! 
Please attend the public opening on Friday, September 23rd which is held in conjunction with the Cultural Trust Fall Gallery Crawl. 
We would also love to see you at our Community Forum: Stories from Uganda on September 29th at Gallery 937 in downtown Pittsburgh. Reception at 6 p.m. and Talk at 7 p.m. Free and open to the public. 
Please check out these organizations that support children in Uganda. 
ASA Social Fund for Hidden Peoples
http://www.asasocialfundforhiddenpeoples.org
Bright Kids Uganda - Africa
http://brightkidsuganda.net
Noah's Ark Hands on Training Center
http://noahsarkug.org 
Stay up to date on the exhibit and related events by giving us a "like" on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/InUgandaByMarthaRial/?...

story:
The Story

I graduated last summer with a degree in photography from Sheffield Hallam Photography, after which I spent a couple of months unemployed before taking a job au pairing in Paris for 6 months. Unfortunately since that has come to an end and I've returned to the UK there are just as few jobs around. I've got a job in a pub, but the hours vary from 30 hours one week to 8 hours the next, which leaves me financially stranded. Right now I'm unable to move back to Sheffield to find work because of being on an NHS waiting list (and I'd have to go back to the end of the queue if I moved again).

So where does this leave me? Well, it leaves me in Bourne, Lincolnshire, living with my dad and his fiancée, with no car and very little in the way of job prospects. However! It's not all doom and gloom... Because on the weeks where I have very few shifts leaves me with plenty of "free" time. Which has led to me beginning several personal projects. Including mini-projects documenting local clubs, like the Scrabble club and the local Crown Green Bowling club, and a bigger project Bourne in general. As well as trying to continue my project about the Women's Institute nationwide.


What is Needed & What You Get

The money you donate would specifically buy a lighting kit (something I had previously borrowed from university, and didn't think that I'd miss so much!) which would make it possible to do the portrait sittings of the members of the WI, Crown Green Bowling club, and the Scrabble club. The light kit is also a fantastic general investment for me, which is why it is a priority. Secondly the money would help towards paying for a high quality printer, which would make it much cheaper and faster for me to produce high quality prints, which is very important! 

The end result will be a local exhibition and an online gallery with prints available. I would like to exhibit further away but that is something that I would have to apply for further in to the project, but I will keep you posted!

Basically at the moment I have somewhere between 5 and 10 % of a project done... Your donation would make it possible for me to complete the project, the rest is legwork!

story:
Underwater Photo Project

For the longest time, I've watched all the nature documentaries, especially those about the ocean, and I was tired of seeing these amazing scenes on TV and not in person. So about 4 years ago, I got scuba certified, and took a camera underwater, and I found out that just here in Northern California, the marine life is amazing and beautiful, and also, I was really good at taking underwater photos. Since I started, my photos have been seen in California Diving News and featured on the Defenders of Wildlife website. I've also been recognized in a number photo contests in the past 3 years.

Because of the encouragement and interest from friends and family, I've been wanting to get this project started for a while. This project is to create a book featuring primarily underwater photography taken in California. The book will contain my best photos taken both above and under the water from various locations in California, descriptions of the photo subjects, how the photos were taken and any important techniques used, and other related information. From what I've seen in the last couple years, there have been very few books published since digital photography has taken off in the underwater scene, and many people are unaware how amazing California is underwater. To do this, I need your help. And if you help me, I'll also helping out a local cause that is incredibly valuable to everyone that scuba divers and others in the Monterey area.  If I receive enough funding. The project should start in May and run through September, with a possible extension of 1 or 2 months depending on progress.

What I Need & What You Get

I'm looking to raise $5000 after fees are deducted, which will be used for the following:

  • Some equipment and travel needed for the project.
  • Production of the photo book and select items that will be provided to people that donate at certain levels.
  • A portion of the money raised will go to the Pacific Grove Hyperbaric Chamber Fund. Due to cuts in funding, the chamber facility had been closed for several months and has only recently been able to restart operations. This is a hugely important facility in the Monterey area that has been in desperate need of money for upkeep and operation given the fact the area is one of the most popular scuba diving locations in the country.

Your Donations:

The following is a breakdown of donation levels:

  • Those that donate $35 or higher will receive a copy of the finished photo book, and $5 of this donation level will go to the Pacific Grove Hyperbaric Chamber Fund. I've also added an additional $35 level for those that want to help out and also donate to the Pacific Grove Hyperbaric Chamber Fund, but don't want a photo book.
  • Those that donate $25-$30 will receive a collection of select photos and videos taken during the project on either DVD or USB drive. I know it's not much, but I hope people will enjoy this.
  • Donations of anything $25 or below will be greatly appreciated. For those people that are local divers interested in getting started in underwater photography, I would be happy to help out in any way I can. I don't claim to be an expert, but I've learned a few things so far. I would be happy arrange days to go diving for those that want to get in the water and take some photos.  ;)
  • $25 and $35 are not the only donation amounts. If you want to donate $1, $2, $5, $40, or more, any amount of donations are welcome.
  • Any remaining money at the end of the project will go to the Pacific Grove Hyperbaric Chamber Fund. I have no intention of pocketing any money when I am finished with this.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate or aren't interested in donating, please let your friends or anyone else you know that would be interested about this project. This is the first time I've attempted something like this, but I'm passionate about doing this and hope those that take part is this will be happy will the results. Thank you for your support.


Finally

I'm hoping this will be a starting point. I wanted to do something like for a good cause to begin with, and if successful, I'm hoping to work on more projects in the future. Please lend me your support. Thank you.

story:
12 Sites in Maine You May Not Have Heard of is a photography book with description of the locations, the best times in the year to visit them and trail maps to get to the location if it does require a longer walk than one mile. 

Why those 12 particular sites? 

Maine is a great attraction for its breathtaking Wildlife Refuges and State Parks. But there are many hidden treasures or ones that aren't apparent. When I first explained my project, I received suggestions of popular places like Baxter, Acadia and Reid State Park. But there are many more out there that I would qualify just as worth-seeing. 

Here is the list:

  1. Mount Bigelow

  2. Gulf Hagas

  3. Moxie Falls

  4. Coos Canyon

  5. Tumbledown Mountain

  6. Saddleback and the Ridge

  7. Camden Hills State Park

  8. Dedham Mountain

  9. Wolfe’s Neck Woods State Park

  10. Quoddy Head State Park

  11. Penobscot Narrows Bridge

  12. Horse Mountain to Traveler Mountain

Photographs

I would like them to be printed in high quality and spreading on two pages each to maximize the visual experience of the photographic book. 

Information

All info about the location will be printed on each side folds. They will fold back inside the book.

Importance

This final project is for my "Graphic Design II" class. It is a major project that will count towards my Graphic Design minor at the University of Maine and as well as my final professional portfolio for prospect job opportunities. 

Time Frame

This project has to be completed and printed by December 10th. I would like to start hiking and shooting as soon as possible before it snows. I would love to take a few photographs once there will be snow on the mountains as well.

Budget and Cost Breakdown

Gas: $364

Meals for day trips: $100

Equipment rental: $40

Color Book & Poster Printing: $100

$604 rounded to a $600 total cost of the project.

__________

Thank you for reading and taking interest in my project!

story:
Buy The Book!

Sky Crystals is currently available for sale for those that missed out on the funding campaign!
Get the hardcover book dedicated to the science and photography of snowflakes here:

http://www.skycrystals.ca/


Project Background

Photography is often a gateway to learning about the world around you. For as long as I have been a professional photographer, I have made the study and photography of snowflakes my winter passion. The project has taught me more than I could have imagined about physics, light, beauty and how we see the world. This book is the culmination of my snowflake project; I want to share all of my knowledge, images and inspiration with the world in a book that will last forever.

 

Details

The book is currently set to the following:

- 300 pages

- Hardcover, case-bound image-wrapped (I'm not a fan of "dust jackets")

- 8.5” square

The book will contain all of my snowflake images, and will detail every photographic and editing technique used in their creation – and I encourage you to try it for yourself! The book will also contain all of the science and physics of snowflakes that I can share without personally having a degree in molecular dynamics. I’ll keep the explanations easy to understand and graphic, but the science is fascinating and there are still many unanswered questions. The human mind will also be explored in this book, trying to unravel the mysteries of why­ we find snowflakes so beautiful and captivating.

 

Why Snowflakes?

Snowflakes: These tiny creations of winter have been a curiosity during most childhoods spent in Canada. As I grew up, I became less and less interested in these “trivial” curiosities, and only recently reconnected with them through the lens of my camera. As with most macro subjects, when photographing snowflakes there are many “what the heck is that?” moments as something mysterious is captured, and that childhood curiosity is reborn.

Using a steady hand, an old mitten, and freshly falling snow, you can produce an image worthy of sparking that childhood wonder in even the most jaded onlookers. Some people don’t believe my images are real, and that’s when I know I’ve created something worth talking about. Of course, some people simply think I’m crazy watching me take pictures of an old mitten in a snow storm.

Standing in frigid temperatures a meter away from comfort and warmth can be a daunting task. Using macro equipment that gives you incredibly little focus, it can be hard to even find a snowflake in the viewfinder. Freezing hands and shivering arms can make the situation worse. However, once you’ve got your first snowflake, you’ll smile at every snowfall from then on. But until you succeed, people will think you’re crazy for trying.

(Written as the cover description of Outdoor Photography Canada magazine issue 20, which featured one of my snowflake images.)

 

Quality

The book will be offset printed and the quality on each page will be outstanding. To showcase the details captured in each snowflake image, please take a look at this page: http://skycrystals.ca/magic-in-the-details/ - zoom in and navigate around the snowflake!

 

The Impact

I need the funds to publish the book, and without your support it simply can't happen. By purchasing a copy of the book through this campaign, you'll help in the book's creation for yourself and for others to enjoy.

In the changing world of publishing, self-publishing a book in this way is finally possible. With your support, this project will become a reality. Without it, all I can offer is scattered images and ramblings on snowflake science in the dark corners of the internet.

It's also my goal to have enough funding to get this book into libraries across North America and beyond.

 

Extra Perks

Greeting Cards: My snowflakes are available as thought-provoking greeting cards (blank inside, you provide the thoughts!). Each box contains 10 cards, each one different. By contributing a little extra you'll receive these cards to share with friends and family.

Fine Art Prints: A finished size of 14"x14" matted & framed, these prints make a wonderful accent to your home and will certain spark conversation. I produce them on a wonderful metallic satin paper that provides a subliminal shimmer to the image. You choose whichever snowflake image is your favourite!

Outdoor Photography Canada Subscription: As a regular contributor to Outdoor Photography Canada, you'll find my musings in the "Beginner's Basics" column of every issue. The magazine has offered to give away a number of 1-year subscriptions to contributors of this project!

Mittens: All of my snowflakes are photographed on a home-made black mitten, made by my grandma. If you're keen on replicating my work, I have just the thing. My grandmother has offered to knit some extra mittens to give away! She's only making a few, so consider it a valuable perk. :)

Preserved Snowflakes: Using techniques developed in the 1940's by Vincent J. Schaefer, I have been preserving snowflakes with a 1% solution of Formvar. This resin traps the snowflake structure on a microscope slide, hardens and leaves an impression of the original snowflake to marvel at. I have very few of these, as they are quite difficult to create. They will come in a small presentation box for safekeeping.

Limited Edition Book: Leather-bound hardcover, silver gilded edges, embossed cover, autographed and one of only 25 ever produced. I'll even add extra images to this book - it won't simply be better presentation. If you're a collector of fine art or books, consider this!

 

Stretch Goals

If I receive more than $15,000 in funding for this project, there are a number of enhancements I’d like to do for the project. A larger size would be great, fitting into a 10”x10” footprint. I could afford to hire a layout designer or editor to improve the quality on each page, or add additional content and images. It would be nice to produce more copies as well, which would allow me to offer the book at major retail locations and give copies away to libraries.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Share this campaign with everyone - at the very least they'll enjoy the snowflake images. Spreading the message for this campaign is integral to its success, and I appreciate every little bit.

I have very few of these, as they are quite difficult to create. They will come in a small presentation box for safekeeping.Limited Edition Book: Leather-bound hardcover, silver gilded edges, embossed cover, autographed and one of only 25 ever produced. Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of passionate photography students thrilled to be exhibiting our final degree work in London at Freerange 2013. This exhibition gives us a unique opportunity to showcase our work to a large and influential audience from both the fine-art and commercial photography world, and connect directly with important individuals within the industry. With the generous support of Napier University we have secured our place at the exhibition from the 13th to 17th of June. However, in order to get down to London and present our work in the most professional manner we still need to raise some much needed funds.

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help this fundraising campaign will cover our work's transportation from Edinburgh to London and back; provide accomodation during the exhibition; allow printing of promotional material so that people from the industry can find out about it and contact us after the exhibition; and finally but most importantly to be able to buy all the neccessary materials needed to fill in the empty space we are exhibiting in (lighting, moving walls, projector and monitors).


Any contributions are really appreciated and you will all get our eternal gratitude for helping with such an important part of our careers. There are also some 'perks' that you can get depending on the contribution you make. This could even include an A2 size print signed by the photographer themselves!!!

 

The Impact

As London is one of the most important cities in the world for culture, having the opportunity to exhibit there presents an amazing opportunity to all the participants. Napier's photography students have been at Freerange for the past three years and every year the work attracts more and more interest from the industry and the press. It represents not just the work of the individuals and the University, but also Scottish culture and contemporary photographic art in Scotland on the whole.

This year with your support we intend to make Napier's presence at Freerange even more recognizable and successfull by going there even more prepared than previous years.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you think our fundraising cause is something you would like to get involved with you can share this campaign with friends and family or at your personal blogs so that we get as much attention as possible. You can also help promote the exhibition itself, and all of our individual work, by talking to any individuals or companies you think could be interested.

Freerange website: http://www.free-range.org.uk/

You can see our samples of work here: http://napiercollective.tumblr.com/
story_txt:
Short Summary
We are a group of passionate photography students thrilled to be exhibiting our final degree work in London at Freerange 2013. This exhibition gives us a unique opportunity to showcase our work to a large and influential audience from both the fine-art and commercial photography world, and connect directly with important individuals within the industry. With the generous support of Napier University we have secured our place at the exhibition from the 13th to 17th of June. However, in order to get down to London and present our work in the most professional manner we still need to raise some much needed funds.
 
What We Need & What You Get


With your help this fundraising campaign will cover our work's transportation from Edinburgh to London and back; provide accomodation during the exhibition; allow printing of promotional material so that people from the industry can find out about it and contact us after the exhibition; and finally but most importantly to be able to buy all the neccessary materials needed to fill in the empty space we are exhibiting in (lighting, moving walls, projector and monitors).
Any contributions are really appreciated and you will all get our eternal gratitude for helping with such an important part of our careers. There are also some 'perks' that you can get depending on the contribution you make. This could even include an A2 size print signed by the photographer themselves!!!
 
The Impact


As London is one of the most important cities in the world for culture, having the opportunity to exhibit there presents an amazing opportunity to all the participants. Napier's photography students have been at Freerange for the past three years and every year the work attracts more and more interest from the industry and the press. It represents not just the work of the individuals and the University, but also Scottish culture and contemporary photographic art in Scotland on the whole.
This year with your support we intend to make Napier's presence at Freerange even more recognizable and successfull by going there even more prepared than previous years.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you think our fundraising cause is something you would like to get involved with you can share this campaign with friends and family or at your personal blogs so that we get as much attention as possible. You can also help promote the exhibition itself, and all of our individual work, by talking to any individuals or companies you think could be interested.
