story:
PHOTO GALLERY

Click all the blue text to get more information.

Why You Should Give

I cannot attend this trip without YOUR donations. If you cannot give at this time I only ask that you share this campaign with 1 other person or through social media.

  • Your donation of ANY amount will go directly toward making the world a better place for one student in Senegal, one school, one community.
  • You will be supporting the driving passion of youth by empowering us to learn more about the wide variety of people and cultures on planet Earth, discovering issues and injustices, and taking action.
  • The "perks" become more sentimental and meaningful with each increase in donation. The greater your donation, the greater influence YOU have and the greater reward you will receive.
___________________________________________________________________________________

The Trip

6 of us "Teen Masterminds" are traveling to Senegal on December 26th for two weeks to work with our peers and staff at the Nduouhh Thiarokh school in Mbour in and Fontaine in Guediawaye.

Goals: The trip to Senegal is primarily for the empowerment of my international peers to take conscious action and reach above and beyond their dreams. More specifically, myself and the group want to:

  • Repair and refurbish the majority of the desks in the classrooms as they are often broken or simply inadequate.
  • Deliver and instruct upon the textbooks and other basic educational supplies and provide technology training for the computers brought and installed.
  • Provide leadership training to students so that they can feel as empowered as we do to make change for themselves, those in their community, and all people on our planet.
  • Open a forum for discussing local and worldly issues and introducing students to systems thinking.
  • Grow as a group and individually as thoughtful leaders, compassionate people, and conscious global citizens.
  • Explore cultural and religious differences and tolerance.
  • Create and bring back works of art, reports, photographs, writings, and other media that can be brought back and presented to friends, family, and others interested in the trip. We hope that this will raise awareness for the needs of global education.
  • Provide educational assistance to like-minded students. For example, I will be studying with a student there also interested in medicine.
  • To bond, and create lasting friendships with our brothers and sisters across the globe. As the Black Eyed Peas said, we are all "one tribe, one people".

~ ~ ~

Expenses: If you're going to donate your hard earned cash, I think it's only fair that you know exactly where it's going.


  • Educational Supplies ($1800) - Science, English and maths textbooks for the Ndioukh Thiarokh and Fontaine schools, both severely understocked with any reference materials. Traditional learning still has its place, but we understand digital literacy is just as important in the modern age. Thus, to buildings that the ratio of computers to students is nearly 1:1000, we hope to bring or purchase laptops so that students can learn to work more efficiently, and use this wonderful educational tool called the internet that we take for granted.
  • Airfare ($1200-$1800) - Round trip from Boston to Dakar, w/ layovers. Cheapest flight options available will be chosen.
  • Living expenses and food ($600) - We will be renting an apartment for Spark that is only hundreds of dollars per year so that we can have a home base in Senegal that will be function as an international office to be maintained by our peers there, making it easy to plan future service trips, maintain connections, and give them a place to hold their own leadership trainings or other events. This will maximize the lasting impact that our group has in Guediwaye.

Those of us in Spark want to make it very clear that we're not just a charitable organization. We don't simply give blindly and hope that our endeavors will make meaningful change, because one thing we've learned is that direct action is 100% of the time more effective and sincere. In Senegal we'll be working hands on, getting down and dirty with locals to discover what aid they truly need.

___________________________________________________________________________________

Photography and Poetry

The plain truth is I love taking photos and writing poems. I love transforming a moment into a work of art, and I hope you can find the appreciation to enjoy my work as much as I enjoy making it. I shoot with an older DSLR on some cheap, vintage lenses, so I'm sometimes limited by my gear. But one lesson I've learned is that you don't need expensive equipment to be a great artist. In Senegal, I fully intend to shoot and write everyday and bring back some amazing work for you to enjoy. However I can't get there without your support. 

Many of the "perks" for your donations include hand signed works of art that can be selected from my prints gallery (or anywhere else on the site).Once you've selected your perk, follow the specific instructions for choosing photos or poems. All perks will be distributed in late January 2014.

___________________________________________________________________________________

About Spark

Spark540° is a group of young leaders who have come together to use the collective power of their youth to make change. Spark's goals are to foster:

1) personal growth - understanding one's strengths and weaknesses so that each individual can develop their talents, and become more compassionate, loving, and effective people

2) communal knowledge - learning about the population and issues that one's community (school, neighborhood, city/town) faces and giving their time and resources to work towards local solutions

3) global awareness - developing the ability to relate local problems to international ones, empathizing with global despair, poverty, violence and injustice, and building upon critical thinking skills. 

4) action - empowering others by spreading one's wealth; we believe that poverty has nothing to do with material objects or money, but rather that happiness, love, balance, and compassion for others are what make you rich or poor. Cash and "things" can always be replaced, attained or given away. However the ability to self actualize, dream, achieve and build sustaining relationships is to us, the most valuable currency. We will travel nationally and internationally, working hands on, getting down and dirty with the locals to spread the wealth and create long standing connections.

Spark was founded because of the aspirations of one teenager - lost in the needs and distractions of life, but found again when her daughter took selfless action. It reminded her that it's never too late, and so she got together a group of teens, and like a Katamari of positive energy we have begun to lay a path for progress and teen empowerment. We were the pioneers, but in years to come Spark will grow beyond our dreams.

___________________________________________________________________________________

About Chase

Chase Marshall Duffin epitomizes the multi-faceted person, with interests and skills ranging from computer technology, to photography and medicine. Chase is a senior at Salem High School where he is a three-season athlete (football, swimming, and track), section leader in the Marching, Concert and Jazz Band playing the trumpet, Co-chair of the student council, and a member of the National Honors Society, the Tri-M Music Honors Society, and various clubs.

Throughout his life Chase has always pictured his success with the uplifting of others, and knew early on in his high school years that he wanted to devote his life to the service of others. He has a passion for community service that he found in elementary school where he and his classmates led the Wreaths of Hope program, creating beautiful origami wreaths during the holiday seasons and donating proceeds to what was then the Crombie Street Shelter. More recently, he attended a service trip to New Orleans with local teens and leaders from the YMCA and Salem High School where participants spent a week rebuilding homes with the St. Bernard Project and Americorps, doing necessary garden work at a community center in the Lower Ninth Ward and with Bayou Restore, and beach cleanup with the National Parks Service at Ship Island in the Gulf. He will attend this trip again in 2014. After high school, Chase will focus in pre-med studies and dreams of earning his medical degree as a general physician or surgeon and joining a “floating” medical association program, such as Doctors Without Borders or Floating Doctors, and eventually starting or joining clinics in remote, developing areas where medical care is limited. 

You can follow Chase's creative works through his webspace at www.meridiantphoto.com.
story_txt:
PHOTO GALLERYClick all the blue text to get more information.Why You Should GiveI cannot attend this trip without YOUR donations. If you cannot give at this time I only ask that you share this campaign with 1 other person or through social media.
Your donation of ANY amount will go directly toward making the world a better place for one student in Senegal, one school, one community.
You will be supporting the driving passion of youth by empowering us to learn more about the wide variety of people and cultures on planet Earth, discovering issues and injustices, and taking action.
The "perks" become more sentimental and meaningful with each increase in donation. The greater your donation, the greater influence YOU have and the greater reward you will receive.
___________________________________________________________________________________The Trip6 of us "Teen Masterminds" are traveling to Senegal on December 26th for two weeks to work with our peers and staff at the Nduouhh Thiarokh school in Mbour in and Fontaine in Guediawaye.Goals: The trip to Senegal is primarily for the empowerment of my international peers to take conscious action and reach above and beyond their dreams. More specifically, myself and the group want to:Repair and refurbish the majority of the desks in the classrooms as they are often broken or simply inadequate.Deliver and instruct upon the textbooks and other basic educational supplies and provide technology training for the computers brought and installed.Provide leadership training to students so that they can feel as empowered as we do to make change for themselves, those in their community, and all people on our planet.Open a forum for discussing local and worldly issues and introducing students to systems thinking.Grow as a group and individually as thoughtful leaders, compassionate people, and conscious global citizens.Explore cultural and religious differences and tolerance.Create and bring back works of art, reports, photographs, writings, and other media that can be brought back and presented to friends, family, and others interested in the trip. We hope that this will raise awareness for the needs of global education.Provide educational assistance to like-minded students. For example, I will be studying with a student there also interested in medicine.To bond, and create lasting friendships with our brothers and sisters across the globe. As the Black Eyed Peas said, we are all "one tribe, one people".~ ~ ~Expenses: If you're going to donate your hard earned cash, I think it's only fair that you know exactly where it's going.
Educational Supplies ($1800) - Science, English and maths textbooks for the Ndioukh Thiarokh and Fontaine schools, both severely understocked with any reference materials. Traditional learning still has its place, but we understand digital literacy is just as important in the modern age. Thus, to buildings that the ratio of computers to students is nearly 1:1000, we hope to bring or purchase laptops so that students can learn to work more efficiently, and use this wonderful educational tool called the internet that we take for granted.

Airfare ($1200-$1800) - Round trip from Boston to Dakar, w/ layovers. Cheapest flight options available will be chosen.
Living expenses and food ($600) - We will be renting an apartment for Spark that is only hundreds of dollars per year so that we can have a home base in Senegal that will be function as an international office to be maintained by our peers there, making it easy to plan future service trips, maintain connections, and give them a place to hold their own leadership trainings or other events. This will maximize the lasting impact that our group has in Guediwaye.
Those of us in Spark want to make it very clear that we're not just a charitable organization. We don't simply give blindly and hope that our endeavors will make meaningful change, because one thing we've learned is that direct action is 100% of the time more effective and sincere. In Senegal we'll be working hands on, getting down and dirty with locals to discover what aid they truly need.___________________________________________________________________________________
Photography and Poetry
The plain truth is I love taking photos and writing poems. I love transforming a moment into a work of art, and I hope you can find the appreciation to enjoy my work as much as I enjoy making it. I shoot with an older DSLR on some cheap, vintage lenses, so I'm sometimes limited by my gear. But one lesson I've learned is that you don't need expensive equipment to be a great artist. In Senegal, I fully intend to shoot and write everyday and bring back some amazing work for you to enjoy. However I can't get there without your support. Many of the "perks" for your donations include hand signed works of art that can be selected from my prints gallery (or anywhere else on the site).Once you've selected your perk, follow the specific instructions for choosing photos or poems. All perks will be distributed in late January 2014.___________________________________________________________________________________
About Spark
Spark540° is a group of young leaders who have come together to use the collective power of their youth to make change. Spark's goals are to foster:1) personal growth - understanding one's strengths and weaknesses so that each individual can develop their talents, and become more compassionate, loving, and effective people2) communal knowledge - learning about the population and issues that one's community (school, neighborhood, city/town) faces and giving their time and resources to work towards local solutions3) global awareness - developing the ability to relate local problems to international ones, empathizing with global despair, poverty, violence and injustice, and building upon critical thinking skills. 4) action - empowering others by spreading one's wealth; we believe that poverty has nothing to do with material objects or money, but rather that happiness, love, balance, and compassion for others are what make you rich or poor. Cash and "things" can always be replaced, attained or given away. However the ability to self actualize, dream, achieve and build sustaining relationships is to us, the most valuable currency. We will travel nationally and internationally, working hands on, getting down and dirty with the locals to spread the wealth and create long standing connections.Spark was founded because of the aspirations of one teenager - lost in the needs and distractions of life, but found again when her daughter took selfless action. It reminded her that it's never too late, and so she got together a group of teens, and like a Katamari of positive energy we have begun to lay a path for progress and teen empowerment. We were the pioneers, but in years to come Spark will grow beyond our dreams.___________________________________________________________________________________About ChaseChase Marshall Duffin epitomizes the multi-faceted person, with interests and skills ranging from computer technology, to photography and medicine. Chase is a senior at Salem High School where he is a three-season athlete (football, swimming, and track), section leader in the Marching, Concert and Jazz Band playing the trumpet, Co-chair of the student council, and a member of the National Honors Society, the Tri-M Music Honors Society, and various clubs.Throughout his life Chase has always pictured his success with the uplifting of others, and knew early on in his high school years that he wanted to devote his life to the service of others. He has a passion for community service that he found in elementary school where he and his classmates led the Wreaths of Hope program, creating beautiful origami wreaths during the holiday seasons and donating proceeds to what was then the Crombie Street Shelter. More recently, he attended a service trip to New Orleans with local teens and leaders from the YMCA and Salem High School where participants spent a week rebuilding homes with the St. Bernard Project and Americorps, doing necessary garden work at a community center in the Lower Ninth Ward and with Bayou Restore, and beach cleanup with the National Parks Service at Ship Island in the Gulf. He will attend this trip again in 2014. After high school, Chase will focus in pre-med studies and dreams of earning his medical degree as a general physician or surgeon and joining a “floating” medical association program, such as Doctors Without Borders or Floating Doctors, and eventually starting or joining clinics in remote, developing areas where medical care is limited. You can follow Chase's creative works through his webspace at www.meridiantphoto.com.

story:
Last year, I spent 6 months walking in the woods, setting up my tent every night, filtering my water from questionable (and sometimes beautiful) sources, thumbing a 1/2 mile ride to town because... well, if it ain't passing a white blaze, it doesn't count!  And, of course, when in town, shoveling food in my mouth voraciously all the while with a shameless grin.  I met Miss Janet, Bob Peoples, Warren Doyle, and so many other legends and angels (most who are unknown but I couldn't have done it without them - THANK YOU, Mother Nature!)

When I got back to 'civilization', I felt a disconnect (as most hikers do). It was a hard transition back to four walls and a steady job. Worse yet, there were countless hikers I had met that I had no idea how to get in touch with.  Sure, there were those I had summit-ed Mt. Katahdin with and others that had exchanged our real names.  But what about Side Show?  How do I find him?  Or Sleep Walker, who I met back in the Smokies, but I never got her real name?

And that's when it hit me. I want to capture the FACE of the Appalachian Trail. That way, I won't feel so lonely when I look at civilized, clean-shaven suburbia where I live.  And NOT just the face.  I want to put the NAMES with the faces. Patchouli is Sarah B----.  Pilgrim is Isaac T------.   And, given their permission, I want to know Patchouli's, er... Sarah's email and how to get a hold of her after the Trail.  Oh, and who was that tall, skinny guy with the beard (no, the other tall, skinny guy with a beard)?  Right, there's his picture.  Oh, I forgot his Trail Name, but now I can friend him on Facebook because I recognized his FACE, and I have a NAME. 

From that wish, a plan was forged...

I hired a photographer and went to Trail Days, where a sleepy little town of 800 people and no hotels annually houses 30,000 current and former hikers of the AT. I didn't know if I'd be successful, or if any other hiker would want what I wanted to put together...  But I was met with a overwhelming "YES!  PLEASE!!!"  The hikers were excited about having a yearbook all of their own, about them, for them, and to create the on-going community - over years and years - of the Appalachian Trail, once we're all off of it.  

We took over 550 pictures of hikers - and not just 2014'ers.  SO MANY years were represented.  All the way back to the 2nd thru-hiker ever... Gene Espy. This yearbook isn't just for those folks hiking in 2014. It's for ALL years, for ALL hikers, whether you've thru-hiked or section-hiked. If you love the Trail too, I want to present you with the FACE of the AT.  And maybe you are it too.

Not only does the team have 550+ photos of individual hikers, but we're also compiling candid shots hikers at the Trail Day's parade, on the trail, in trail towns, with trail angels, and by trail magic.  After all, the Trail is about its hikers. 

I hope that you will consider helping us fund our dream. We have reached out to the trail and it has welcomed us with open arms. This is our way to give back to the many faces and names that have shaped us and changed us on our thru-hikes. 

With successful funding, we will be able to go to print in August with an anticipated delivery date in September - about the time our newest thru-hiker class will be making their summits and heading back to us! The team at The Hiker Yearbook would love nothing more than to offer them this memory and connection back to their Trail.  Thank you for reading!

story:
Printed & Framed.. Photos, Delivered 

I just gave Pentax K20D SLR away because it had its limitations beside it being a very good camera. I've made about USD600 by selling it and now I need to move to a full frame camera and get some lenses. You can help me out and I can pay back in return with printed or framed photos of your choice from my flickr page. If you don't wanna hang those photos on your walls yet don't mind helping me out, of course you can still donate some of your hard earned money for this cause and I'd always be grateful. I'm also trying to sell other remaining lenses and add money to the project.

So, depending on the money we raise, I'd go for a Full Frame DSLR few key lenses to kick-start my obsession.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can spread the news within your network of friends it might also be very helpful.. 


Check out my Flickr page

story:
Photography and media for change

Hello! Lumelang! Moi! My name is Meri Hyöky. I am a professional photographer and web designer. I am originally from Finland, but I have lived in the US for much of my life. In 2011, I travelled to Lesotho in Southern Africa as part of the crew of the film The Forgotten Kingdom. Very quickly, I fell in love with the breathtaking scenery, incredible people and rich culture of this tiny mountain kingdom. Only a month after the completion of filming, I found that I had left behind my life in North Carolina, and had returned to Lesotho.

I have spent the majority of the past two years living in Morija, a small town in Lesotho. Despite its natural beauty and the warmth of its people, Lesotho is a country with many sobering realities: it has the third highest HIV prevalence rate in the world, much of the population lives in poverty, and for many people every day is a struggle to make ends meet.

During my time in Lesotho, I have used my skills to help many organisations and movements that are working to effect positive change in the country. These include Morija Museum & Archives and the Morija Arts & Cultural Festival (www.morija.co.ls), Flava of Africa (www.flavaofafrica.wordpress.com) and Africa’s Green Generation (http://africasgreengeneration.wordpress.com/).

Together with my friend and colleague Sejake Mats'ela, I have also founded Uprise Media Centre (www.uprisemediacentre.com) - a new initiative in Morija which will provide the local community with affordable internet access, media training and opportunities for the production of visual art.

Causes in the US that I have worked with in the past few years include:

  • Moore Labs Rescue (Apex, North Carolina) - http://moore-labs.com/
  • Organics & Sounds (Durham, North Carolina) - http://organicsandsound.com/
  • Pickards Mountain Eco-Institute (Chapel Hill, North Carolina) - http://pickardsmountain.org/
  • West Southern Pines Young Leadership Program (Southern Pines, North Carolina)
  • Boys & Girls Clubs of the Sandhills (Southern Pines, North Carolina) -http://sandhillsbgc.org/

In Lesotho and the US, I also use my skills whenever I can to support up-and-coming as well as established artists and musicians.

To me, photography is a tool that allows me to meaningfully and creatively support movements and organisations such as these. Devoting my time and skills to movements and causes that I care about allows me to portray their needs, their work and their successes to a wide audience, helping them to get more exposure, which can lead to funding, support and solidarity from people around the world.

The condition of my camera equipment, however, has severely deteriorated over the years. My Nikon D200, which I have worked with for five years, is falling to pieces. The padding on the outside of the camera has fallen off, I am currently holding my battery in place with a piece of cardboard, and on a technical level there are various functions of the camera which often temperamentally decide to not work. I am increasingly panicked by the number of times it has flashed all manner of error! messages at me in the middle of a photo shoot.

The large majority of the work I do for non-profit organisations is voluntary, and I currently do not have the money to buy new camera equipment.

I am raising funds toward a Nikon D800 camera and a Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G ED AF-S Nikkor Wide Angle Zoom Lens. The Nikon D800, with 36.3 megapixels, is able to capture incredible textures, nuances and details. The Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G ED lens is a versatile lens which can capture wide-angle landscapes and panoramas, portraits and events in a variety of lighting and weather conditions.

My old Nikon D200 has another great disadvantage: it is unable to capture video. One of the most exciting features of the Nikon D800 is that it is able to shoot HD movies. In a recent survey of non-profit organisations, 80% of respondents said that video is important to their organisation (http://tinyurl.com/qgjpdfm). A good quality video is an incredibly powerful medium which non-profit organisations can use to tell real life stories, to give a human face to broad social issues, and to show donors and supporters how their money is being used. This would be a major addition to what I can offer in the work that I do for Uprise and other organisations.

What I Need and What You Get

My fundraising goal is $ 5000. With this money, I will purchase the Nikon D800 camera body (http://tinyurl.com/lhuk3ve) and the Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G ED lens (http://tinyurl.com/ovwlnjz) (The additional money will be used to the pay the fees charged by indiegogo.com).

If the entire amount is not raised by this campaign, I hope to at least acquire the camera body, and improve lenses at a later time.

By making a donation to help me purchase this much-needed upgrade in my camera equipment, you will be making a direct contribution to the work that I do for a wide range of worthwhile causes in Lesotho and the US. In return of your support, I am offering all donors digital copies of photos of their choosing from my collections over the years. To view my photography, please visit the following pages:

http://uprisemediacentre.com/meri-hyoky-photography/

https://www.facebook.com/merihyokyphotography

Photos will be sent in full resolution, with a full release to print and publish (credit given to photographer when published).

Uprise and spread the word!

Be a part of the Uprise movement! Your help will allow me to continue to use my photography to support people and organisations who are working to change lives. All donations - whatever the amount - will be enormously appreciated. If you are not in a position to financially contribute to this campaign, you can still help by spreading the word!

Thank you, Kea leboha, Kiitos!

(Thanks to The Library for providing the music. Produced by Sage. Visit http://goo.gl/0tsd8n to hear more from them)

https://www.facebook.com/merihyokyphotography

story:
We are traveling across the United States visiting some of America's most famous zoos by one of our country's oldest forms of transportation, the train. While in film school, Cozell became addicted to taking pictures at the zoo. He was intrigued by filming wild animals in an urban environment. Now that he has graduated, we are going to see what the rest of the country has to offer as we train through 17 states.The USA Rail Pass is the cheapest way that will allow us to travel the entire country, visiting many cities on a small budget. 

  After doing a little research, we found that most zoos are non-profit and can't just let every photographer/writer duo in for free. Thus we are fundraising to help with admission, travel expenses, and publication of the book. 

  If you can't donate maybe there are other ways you can help. We are traveling through Washington, Oregon, California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Florida, the Carolinas, Maryland, DC, Pennsylvania, New York, and Massachusetts(pending). If you know anybody in these states with ties to wild life, reserves zoos, or amusement parks and could get us in touch with them it would be a great deal of help. Anyone with travel tips and or ways to help us minimize our travel expenses please contact us. We are also looking to get in touch with publishers and printing companies.
 
  We're so excited to learn more about our country while practicing our arts through this journey! Thank you.

If you know anybody in these states with ties to wild life, reserves zoos, or amusement parks and could get us in touch with them it would be a great deal of help. Anyone with travel tips and or ways to help us minimize our travel expenses please contact us. We are also looking to get in touch with publishers and printing companies.
 
  We're so excited to learn more about our country while practicing our arts through this journey! Thank you.

story:
HELP PRODUCE ATHENS POTLUCK, a 424-page, large-format coffee table book.

THE ATHENS POTLUCK STORY

For the past 20 years, I’ve been photographing bands and musicians in Athens, Georgia.

I’ve wanted to make a book about the Athens music scene for a while now, but I just couldn’t wrap my head around how to approach such a broad and complex subject. There are hundreds of bands who call Athens home—and there are so many different parts to our music scene—everything from punk to metal and rock n roll… bluegrass and old time music, pop, electronica, rap…

I also knew I didn’t want to do a typical music book that was just about live music or “bands.” What really interests me is the individual musicians and where they fit into the big picture. So many Athens musicians play in multiple bands or tour with one and record with another, and it’s all interconnected—those connections are what’s really interesting to me.

Finally, my wife Beth suggested the concept that would become Athens Potluck: I’d start by choosing one Athens musician, then ask them to choose the next person to be photographed, and the second person would choose the third, and so on. The organic nature of the project itself took me off the hook—with the musicians making the decisions, Athens Potluck became a self-propelling “stream of consciousness” body of work.

In total, I photographed 33 musicians just as diverse as their art. Visiting each in his or her own personal space, I captured them surrounded by their things, their families or pets, their instruments…and then took their questions for the next musician.

Athens Potluck is really a glimpse into the diverse and secretive nature of the Athens music scene—it’s an inside look at how our artistic environment works, growing and thriving on personal connections. Obviously this project wouldn’t exist without that intense spirit of respect and friendship between the artists.

Athens Potluck will be produced by Deeds, a local Athens company, who are great designers and make beautiful books printed in the USA. The book will be available fall 2017.

We’ve created all kinds of incentives, from small to big—signed books and prints of images from the book, one of a kind “musician interview” art pieces, studio tours with me, and even some events with a few of the artists.

THE PERKS

| the book

| ticket to the Athens Potluck Variety Show at the Georgia Theatre

| 6x9 postcards

| archival prints

| Don Chambers in the burnt out ruins of the Georgia Theatre (13" x 19" print)

| Murmur Trestle prints

 

By supporting this campaign, you are helping me create a quality book that will be a long-lasting archive of Athens, its culture, and the work of art that is its music scene. We can’t wait to get Athens Potluck out into the world.

 

—Jason Thrasher

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kristel Durand, I have been a professional photographer for over 10 years. I have recently recieved my Masters degree in Photography. Between my professional and educational experience I am ready to transition my photographic work and vision from the private sector to the non-profit sector, specifically with foster children. I am asking for help through crowd funding to get the organization up and running.


What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $1000.00 dollars to cover all of the start up costs, primarily the filing fees and legal fees to obtain 501c(3) status.

The Impact

Katchlight will make a huge impact on the lives of foster kids celebrating milestones such as graduating from high school. Many foster children never have the opportunity to have school portraits or professional portraits taken. Katchlight will offer a high quality, complete portrait package to foster kids in the school system.  The portraits will celebrate their achievements, commemorate all of their hard work as well as  give them an oppotunity to participate in a long traditional right of passage that is an american tradition, the senior portrait.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please forward this campaign and help raise awareness! Use the share button to help me get the word out!

story:
Ashleigh Lives for analog

Ever since she got her hands on a Twin Lens Reflex, she has been in love with the rendering, grain, colors, workflow and archival qualities medium format film has to offer. Her biggest fear is that digital photographs can be easily lost as it transfers from hard drive to hard drive. There is no better contender for photo documentation and archiving than the sleek build of a Hasselblad. Having the Hasselblad is important to me because unlike the limitations of my twin lens:

  • I can shoot different formats (6x6 and 6x7)
  • I can switch out lenses with ease
  • I can switch between film types while shooting!

Please support your local photographer/artist/friend so she can keep creating!

What We Need & What You Get

My beautiful Twin Lens Reflex is broken and it requires I send it to Portland to get fixed. But because of the cost of doing this, I think it is a better idea to get a professional grade medium format camera so I can send out my TLR and keep it shooting without DEPENDING on it. I always need photographic equipment. Having medium format back in my life will relieve me of the enormous financial impact purchasing the camera would have on me. You will receive HIGH QUALITY photographic services from a trained professional in the form of prints, shooting or editing in exchange for your support.

Check out www.ashleighcastro.com and my Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/5footassassin/ for reference of available photographs

The Impact

I am a freelance photographer who attends many concerts and documents them FOR FREE. If you support my endeavor in getting this camera you'll also be supporting local musicians who usually can't afford such services, but deserve them.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this link, share my photographs, if someone needs a shoot direct em to me!
